repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: ## Problem - ~200 line function of hard-to-maintain C code. - Local Addition section is unordered and looks messy because of the varying description formats. ## Solution - Move code to Lua. - Sort on alphabetic order. - Have a best-effort approach where short descriptions are right aligned, giving a cleaner look. Long descriptions are untouched. | Before | |--------| | | | After (alphabetic order, descriptions right-aligned) | |--------| | | Note: I excluded Nvim-bundled plugins as they are in the `|standard-plugin-list|` linked right above the local additions.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -122,10 +122,73 @@ function M.escape_subject(word)
     -- E.g. '`command`,' --> 'command' (backticks are removed too, but '``' stays '``')
     word = word:gsub([[^'([^']*)'.*]], [['%1']])
     word = word:gsub([[^{([^}]*)}.*]], '{%1}')
-    word = word:gsub([[^`([^`]+)`.*]], '%1')
+    word = word:gsub([[.*`([^`]+)`.*]], '%1')

@@ -122,10 +122,73 @@ function M.escape_subject(word)
     -- E.g. '`command`,' --> 'command' (backticks are removed too, but '``' stays '``')
     word = word:gsub([[^'([^']*)'.*]], [['%1']])
     word = word:gsub([[^{([^}]*)}.*]], '{%1}')
-    word = word:gsub([[^`([^`]+)`.*]], '%1')
+    word = word:gsub([[.*`([^`]+)`.*]], '%1')
   end
 
   return word
 end
 
+---Populates the |local-additions| section of a help buffer with references to locally-installed
+---help files. These are help files outside of $VIMRUNTIME (typically from plugins) whose first
+---line contains a tag (e.g. *plugin-name.txt*) and a short description.
+---
+---For each help file found in 'runtimepath', the first line is extracted and added to the buffer
+---as a reference (converting '*tag*' to '|tag|'). If a translated version of a help file exists
+---in the same language as the current buffer (e.g. 'plugin.nlx' alongside 'plugin.txt'), the
+---translated version is preferred over the '.txt' file.
+function M.local_additions()
+  local buf = vim.api.nvim_get_current_buf()
+  local bufname = vim.fs.basename(vim.api.nvim_buf_get_name(buf))
+
+  -- "help.txt" or "help.??x" where ?? is a language code, see |help-translated|.
+  local lang = bufname:match('^help%.(%a%a)x$')
+  if bufname ~= 'help.txt' and not lang then
+    return
+  end
+
+  -- Find local help files
+  local plugins = {}
+  local pattern = lang and ('doc/*.{txt,%sx}'):format(lang) or 'doc/*.txt'
+  for _, docpath in ipairs(vim.api.nvim_get_runtime_file(pattern, true)) do
+    if not vim.fs.relpath(vim.env.VIMRUNTIME, docpath) then
+      -- '/path/to/doc/plugin.txt' --> 'plugin'
+      local plugname = vim.fs.basename(docpath):sub(1, -5)
+      -- prefer language-specific files over .txt
+      if not plugins[plugname] or vim.endswith(plugins[plugname], '.txt') then
+        plugins[plugname] = docpath
+      end
+    end
+  end
+
+  -- Format plugin list lines
+  local lines = {}
+  for _, path in vim.spairs(plugins) do
+    local fp = io.open(path, 'r')
+    if fp then
+      local tagline = fp:read('*l') or ''
+      fp:close()

comment_data.body: I only need to read the first line. Seems that readblob can only read first X bytes (or whole file). If there's a more elegant approach to reading the first line lmk :)
comment_data.diff_hunk:

+    if fp then

+      fp:close()

comment_data.body: No, this is pretty much the way to do it. One could think of adding a `vim.readline` (placeholder name) wrapper to reduce boilerplate also for plugins, but I don't think it's worth for such a short and simple snippet.

comment_data.body: since `test/old/testdir/test_help.vim` covers the layout do we actually need this test?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -151,4 +151,32 @@ describe(':help', function()
     command('help â€¦')
     eq('*â€¦*', api.nvim_get_current_line())
   end)
+
+  it('help.txt local additions is populated', function()

comment_data.body: Good point. No, I don't think so. I'll remove them.

comment_regular_data.body: Sorry for the multiple canceled auto-merges @justinmk ðŸ˜…. Noticed one possible bug: used `#string` instead of `vim.fn.strdisplaywidth()`.
try rebasing? CI doesn't look good

Still the same test that fails, `test/functional/ui/messages_spec.lua:428`. I don't see why that test would fail because of this PR, although some lines above the help.txt doc is opened... Maybe @luukvbaal could take a look at the failing test? I can't reproduce it on my Mac

to unblock this, perhaps skip if `t.is_asan()` around that specific part of `messages_spec.lua`


```
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8535977Z = AddressSanitizer: heap-buffer-overflow
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8536860Z = READ of size 4097 at 0x521000211d00 thread T0
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8537757Z =     #0 0x562f7a1e5d3d in strrchr (â€¦/build/bin/nvim+0xcc8d3d)
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8538873Z =     #1 0x562f7af67a00 in msg_puts_display â€¦/src/nvim/message.c:2357:28
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8539739Z =     #2 0x562f7af5fedf in msg_puts_len â€¦/src/nvim/message.c:2311:5
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8540586Z =     #3 0x562f7af4351b in msg_outtrans_len â€¦/src/nvim/message.c:1835:5
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8541716Z =     #4 0x562f7b18fcc1 in out_data_append_to_screen â€¦/src/nvim/os/shell.c:1141:7
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8542615Z =     #5 0x562f7b18f534 in out_data_cb â€¦/src/nvim/os/shell.c:1156:5
...
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8570851Z = allocated by thread T0 here:
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8571724Z =     #0 0x562f7a269db3 in malloc (â€¦/build/bin/nvim+0xd4cdb3)
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8572790Z =     #1 0x562f7af1fba4 in try_malloc â€¦/src/nvim/memory.c:113:15
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8573577Z =     #2 0x562f7af1fe04 in xmalloc â€¦/src/nvim/memory.c:147:15
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8574410Z =     #3 0x562f7af22a3d in alloc_block â€¦/src/nvim/memory.c:717:12
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8575463Z =     #4 0x562f7a98b573 in rstream_init â€¦/src/nvim/event/rstream.c:43:20
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8576380Z =     #5 0x562f7b18af25 in do_os_system â€¦/src/nvim/os/shell.c:919:3
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8577291Z =     #6 0x562f7b18a03c in os_call_shell â€¦/src/nvim/os/shell.c:691:18
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8578140Z =     #7 0x562f7b18867a in call_shell â€¦/src/nvim/os/shell.c:743:14
2026-02-13T20:17:44.8578952Z =     #8 0x562f7a9add72 in do_shell â€¦/src/nvim/ex_cmds.c:1503:3
```

This is also reproducible on master with the following change:
```diff
diff --git a/src/nvim/memory.c b/src/nvim/memory.c
index ec82848138..215309fa2d 100644
--- a/src/nvim/memory.c
+++ b/src/nvim/memory.c
@@ -674,7 +674,7 @@ void *mergesort_list(void *head, MergeSortGetFunc get_next, MergeSortSetFunc set
   return head;
 }
 
-#define REUSE_MAX 4
+#define REUSE_MAX 0
 
 static struct consumed_blk *arena_reuse_blk;
 static size_t arena_reuse_blk_count = 0;
```
I think it needs to use `memrchr()` instead of `strrchr()`.
Thanks @zeertzjq for the quick debugging and fix! I've rebased so CI should be ok now.

labels.description: changes that are not features or bugfixes
labels.name: refactor

title: refactor(help): move local-additions to Lua
